Most food poisoning is caused by Salmonella bacteria but not once it is in your stomach. It eats your food when it is left out in the kitchen or dining area and after about 4 hours there is enough of its toxic poop on your food to make you sick. So drinking wine will NOT prevent food poisoning. You would have to pour the wine over your food ever half hour or so to slow it down. Rule of thumb is that if food has been been left out for 4 hours it is covered with Salmonella poop and should be discarded. Don't try to cheat by eating food that's been left out longer than that and washing it down with a drink. If you are travelling, though, for example in Mexico or elsewhere where the tap water contains bacteria that you are not accustomed to then mixing in some wine will kill the bacteria and make it safe: "Stop drinking only water, and use a little wine because of your stomach and your frequent illnesses." - 1 Timothy 5:23 (from the Bible)

1 glass of wine or 2 glasses of beer a day?

According to AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test, which is a more or less international agreement) it counts as alcoholism if one drinks more than 9-14 (depending on body type, size etc) standard units of alcohol a week, and a great health risk if one drinks more than 3-4 standard units just after each other.

Even if one glass of wine a day is less than these AUDIT numbers, it’s not that far away from it. And two glasses of beer a day is 14 glasses of beer in a week.
Why is it that when I blow my nose hard enough. The canthus ( corner of your eye) blow a little air

1 glass of wine/2 beers is OK? Why, is it because of the French paradox, which is an old OBSERVATIONAL study that has been totally debunked years ago, says so? Or maybe it is because some studies with clear conflicts of interest that appear in the press every month say things like “Hoppy beers can protect against Alzheimer’s” “Beer is full of vitamins” “Beer makes your bones stronger”, etc.?

The most certain scientific facts we have about alcohol are:
-It causes liver damage EVEN IN SMALL DOSES (<30g/day).
-Alcohol is a carcinogen (at any dose).

So, any press article/Youtube video/health professional talking about the “benefits
of alcoholic beverages” without underlining its downsides is extremely biased (and lots of times you could easily find some conflicts of interest).

It appears that there is a correlation between alcohol consumption and mortality which reverses at the lowest rate of drinking. It appears that very limited daily drinking (1-2 drinks for women, 2-4 drinks from men) is protective.

Citation:
Alcohol dosing and total mortality in men and women: an updated meta-analysis of 34 prospective studies.
Di Castelnuovo A, Costanzo S, Bagnardi V, Donati MB, Iacoviello L, de Gaetano G - Arch. Intern. Med. - December 1, 2006; 166 (22); 2437-45

That was a very interesting video.  Nice balance between being informative, but not boring.

My theory is that heavy drinking feeds certain helpful bacteria and kills certain helpful bacteria. There are, after all, multiple different types of gut bacteria. Some gut bacteria, like Clostridium Difficile, is part of helpful gut bacteria. But all gut bacteria tend to average out others, like the checks and balances of our government are supposed to do. When certain kinds of bacteria die off, other kinds go crazy and can cause illness like the diarrhea of C. Diff infection. We have C. Diff naturally but when things like antibiotics kill off a lot of the C. Diff. controlling bacteria, C. Diff. diarrhea can be the result.

I work as nurse at a hospital on the Medical/Surgical unit where we often admit patients for C. Diff. infections. Sad to say, us nurses can simply take a whiff and look at stool after someone has had a bowel movement and tell if they have C. Diff. (or a gastrointestinal bleed) and tell if their gut is working right.

As a nurse, the stressors of my job have lead to me (and several coworkers) to be borderline alcoholics. I have noticed that after to much alcohol consumption, my gut is not happy at all. I really believe that the alcohol kills off some bacteria but causes some to over-produce. Please pardon the nurse-isms here but, I often notice after a lot of alcohol intake, my BM's are fairly loose and with a bad smell. If I take a probiotic, (to repopulate my gut with good, regulating bacteria) my gut goes back to normal.

Some times, working in the medical field is more fruitful if you pay attention to your own body and put yourself in the position of the patient. Only then can you truly relate.

-S. Hinson
